name: War for the Overworld
description: Tired of invading dungeons? It's time you built your own! War for the Overworld is a Dungeon Management Game that employs your favourite aspects of the RTS and God Game genres. Carve out your Dungeon and conquer the Overworld!

reviews.review_text: Game itself is VERY fun. Dungeon Keeper 2.0(less of a dark theme though, voice overs are good but a bit goofball humor)  Initially there were alot of bugs/glitches but the developers have been releasing patches EVERY 2-3 hours, amazing, 7-8 patches so far  +++++++++++++ support these guys, bug fixing at midnight on a saturday and releasing a patch. This is how game companies should behave (SUPPORT YOUR PRODUCTS!!!!!)

War for the Overworld was a bug-ridden mess when it was first released, but I give enormous credit to the young, inexperienced development team that they stuck with it and did the hard work to fix their game even though the world had already written it off.  Today War for the Overworld is incomparable to what it was immediately after release. As the devs have cleared the bugs out of the way and continued to polish the game underneath, a real gem has emerged with it’s own style.  After giving up on War for the Overworld immediately after release, I went back a few months ago and had a blast, completeing the whole campaign. So far I’ve been loving the additions in this new Hearts of Gold expansion too.  I encourage anyone who was turned off by the initial mess to give War for the Overworld another shot. It’s now a wonderful game in and of itself, but more than that the devs should be congratulated and rewarded for never giving up on their vision.

Buying this game is buying a work in progress. I understand the many folks who were dissapointed that the game is 'unfinished'. The thing that keeps me in the dev's camp on this one is reading their posts. This is a group of little guys, who are being honest and forthright about what's been going on with them, why things are the way they are, and what they are working on for the future. This isn't EA or Blizzard with obfuscation and double talk, this is by the fans, for the fans, and that kind of real honesty is uncommon in both gaming and life in general!   So, to the game. They have masterfully captured the 'flavor' of DK. I have enjoyed the mechanics of the different rooms, and figuring out the spells, rituals, and potions. The graphics are good, they favor the old game without looking dated. I'm playing often, but not constantly, as I enjoy coming back after patches and seeing how they are continuing to put polish on things. Personally am highly looking forward to more Skirmish maps, particularly larger ones! If you like DK, buy this game, and learn to love the progress and the game as is. If you like God mode games, and the idea of being Bad for the first time, well, come give evil a try! ;-)

Feels almost like dungeon keeper 2 and with a little bit of tweaking it will be a really nice DK2 alternative. There's still a lot of bugfixing to do though, but the developer is patching the hell out of it. So have no fear.

Update April 11, 2015:  THE memory leak has been fixed, but the game has such poor performance across the board that the game is unplayable. Still crashes. Still many many bugs and unfinished things. I am way too frustrated trying to play through the broken, unfinished stuff with awful performance.  Beating the final 'boss' doesn't even make sense in the campaign. Maybe there's supposed to be some more cutscenes that explain it that aren't finished/added yet? The overall story is very poorly written.  The campaign is very short, only extended by game crashes or not being able to load game saves because of a 'gc too many threads' error. I'm guessing they beefed up the garbage collection to help with the memory leak but caused another bug in the process??  I can't spawn heroes from the hero gate in the 'My Pet Dungeon' level. I guess they didn't add that functionality yet? Also, I can't get any more of the errr experience points? So I can't unlock all the things. It's just so buggy. There's no real reason to play that level :/  I do not call this a 'spiritual successor' to Dungeon Keeper because DK1 & 2 were actually good whereas this is not. It is not worthy of such a name or comparison.    Visuals: Poor. Low poly models and blah textures without any kind of shading (lighting effects and whatnot) on them. Environment art is better than the character art, but still doesn't feel that great.   Audio: Meh. They got the original DK voice actor, but he doesn't sound as good as I remember him being. He used to have a deeper more sinister or demonic voice. I miss that rumble in his voice when he said 'Keeper'.   Gameplay: Poor. Campaign mission design is weak. Just drop your flag on the enemies heart and it's over. Or get rekt by the AI while you're (graphically) lagging out.   Do NOT buy this game. Your money is better spent elsewhere. I kind of wish I could get a refund :/     ------------------------------------- Original Review April 6, 2015: I recommend NO only because the game was released in a very unfinished state.    There's lots of placeholder text.   Multiplayer lobby is broken.   Part of the 'Possession' spell's tooltip says that attacking and using the unit's abilities doesn't work yet. (It doesn't)   The first level bugged out for me. I killed the group of dwarves in the island but the objective never updated. I probably used the rally flag too many times or something. I don't know. I had to restart it and carefully follow the instruction and then it worked.   Straight up hard crash on the 4th level. It just finished the intro bit about how I have beasts and I was moving the camera around and mining stuff and building things and then suddenly the screen turned white and everything was unresponsive. Had to hard reboot my desktop.   I can't complete the 4th level. After reaching the other keeper, everything gets super choppy and eventually hard crashes my computer. This time with a bright green screen instead of white screen. I'm thinking there's an extra hard memory leak in it :/   Also, the textures aren't that high res and the geometry feels very low poly for a game being released in 2015. Maybe they're trying to really get that Dungeon Keeper 2 feel and visuals. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯  Once the game gets patched up to how it should have been when it was released, I'll reevalute this review. I know the devs are trying hard (multiple patches per day since release), but I just can't recommend the given product right now.

Full disclosure: I bought in during Early Release, however I did not play the game extensively until 1.0.  This game is, by and large, a deep spiritual successor to the great Dungeon Keeper of old, complete with the same narrator in the background, along with the witty humour and dungeon base building concept.  It is brought to the modern day with a more modern control scheme, graphical fidelity, and delivery. If you've ever been a fan of base-building games and/or wanted to be the bad guy, this is your game. Fan of the DK of old? Its back, baby!  + Great successor and spiritual remake of Dungeon Keeper, down to the narrator V/O and core mechanics + Expands on the formula by ading new minion types (with different mechanics rules), minion behaviors, and artifacts that add new abilities + Looks great, feels just like a Dungeon Keeper game, and even sounds right, complete with the minion V/O you can hear from time to time.  - Release jank, and lots of it. No doubt it'll get fixed, but as I'm playing this right as 1.0 has hit, its evident. - Performance and stability issues, from crashing on exit, to FPS slowdown when a lot of worker minions are spawned. - (AT RELEASE, will likely be fixed by the time you read this) No Skirmish or Multiplayer Lobby working yet, as they've had to remove them to fix showstopper bugs. - Sudden difficulty spikes that can run away from the player, particularly the Dwarven survival campaign mission. - Options menu feels a bit bare - 'Possession' mechanic, whilst its in the game, feels just as janky as the original Dungeon Keeper one, complete with odd camera POV, lack of feedback on weapon swings, and when being damaged.

Although the game was an unplayable mess at its original release, War for the Overworld has become an impressive and fun successor to the Dungeon Keeper series after Patch 1.1. It truly felt like I was playing the next logical step, or Dungeon Keeper 3, if you will.  For those uneducated and/or unexperienced in the Dungeon Keeper series, War for the Overworld is a strategy game where you play as the Underlord, the master of a dungeon that you build from the ground up. You dig out the earth surrounding your dungeon core and designate what the tiles that you have dug out are to be repurposed for. Barracks, lairs, torture chambers, prison, sanctuaries, traps, and many, many other rooms are available, all of which have their own unique abilities that they add to your dungeon and most of which that bring in new creatures to serve you in crushing the competing underlords and those pesky human armies that seek to reclaim their land from you.  All in all a great game and one that I highly recommend those fans who have been waiting years for a legitimate sequel to the Dungeon Keeper series.
Despite being released the game still plays like it's in early access. There's still a bunch of placeholders and a lot of bugs. I honestly don't think it's worth the asking price right now.

I have to say I am very pleased with the evolution of this game. Being a huge fan of The bullfrog's Dungeon Keeper series led me to purchase WFTO. Knowing that this game was unfinished when I bought it led me to have some early reservations as I have been burned before on other unfinished games. But the crew that developed this game has been extremely professional and has an ear to the ground for consumer complaints. They have been very good at fixing and polishing their product which I have to say is a breath of fresh air in an industry that has turned from making great games to churning out substandard content in order to make money and decrease risks. I hope they continue on the path they are on and look forward to seeing what they come up with in the future. I believe that this game is one of the best in its genre which is saying a lot seeing as these type of games are dying out. Big name developers watch out for these guys. They are doing it right, and they didn't charge an arm and a leg to do it.

I REALLY wanted this to be good... sadly, I was hugely dissapointed. This is DK2's stupid, violent little brother... not the successor to Dungen Keeper 2.  The maps have almost zero creativity. Most of the time you can not even build a chain of rooms without indestructable blocks stopping you from setting up a decent functioning base.   The beauty of DK2 was the gameplay. Building you base, levelling your minions, gently probing the defenses of your enemy and destroying your enemy a piece at a time. This game has NONE of that!   It has next to no tactics or strategy involved. It plays the same way every time... Build some rooms... defend, defend...Zerg. Build rooms... defend, defend... Zerg.  The gameplay has all the subtly of a runaway train.   The voice acting is great, but it VERY quickly becomes annoying to the point of frustration at the constant yelling at you. Because all the game does is send enemy units to attack you, in every scenario... and almost constantly.   I purchased this on sale... and am SO glad I did not pay full price. Even so, I still feel ripped off.

i do reccomend this game , BUUUUT wait .  even though they say they released the game , it still functions as a game that would be in early beta ?  a lot of isseus stil occur. they are working hard , but i suggest you wait for a bit before you buy , when most of buggs are out

Dungeon Keeper was a fantastic game and I applaud WFTO for picking up the gauntlet that had been discarded for far too long.  The game is what you make of it.  Dont expect to be fed Blizzard/Square Enix/EA, boundary pushing extravaganzas.  This is a game made by serious fans of the genre for the enjoyment of everyone.  What's even more commendable is that it is still evolving and being expanded into something more feature rich and polished. The developer has demonstrated a dedication to WFTO and listens to the community.  So yes it does require a few more tweaks to some features, but these minor details dont outweigh what is already there to be enjoyed.   I will be clocking up many more hours and building many more dungeons.
This is Dungeon Keeper 3... PLain and simple. If you loved DK 1& 2 you will absolutely love this game. Stop thinking and buy it now.

Haveing played Dungeon keeper 2 for years since it first came out even., quite enjoying this game esentualy dungeon keeper 3. however there are certin things i dont like. the main one being steam itself causeing lag on the game. (none steam version on identical machine runs far better)  in regards to if i would recomend it. Entirely depends on if you played dk1 and 2, if you did then you will like this. if you didnt then you better love long god management games.
just like the good old DK2 with some improvement like the tech three.. still some bug but the developper show some will to fix everything.

Extremely Good Campaign so far. Sure ive had weird bugs and glitches but the devs are onto them nearly immediately i have not woken up once since the update where there hasnt been an update to solve them. Truely the way any game should be taken, sure i would like them to have a break and have a nice rest after making this wonderous game but to go beyond that step takes pure commitment so Thumbs up for me xD

It's good but there's a few things that need to be improved.  What I missed the most from the DK games were all the little details that were put into creatures' personalities and traits. For example, you couldn't have spiders and flies share a lair because they hate each other. Bile demons hated skeletons because they're fat and skeletons are skinny so they wouldn't work together. A level 10 demon spawn becomes a dragon, a tentacle only comes if you put a lair next to water. There are DK ersatz characters in this game, like a succubus instead of a mistress, but they're not fleshed out much. I do like how, for example, the Auger is a slow creature, so you have to think about the layout of the rooms he uses so he doesn't have to walk too far, but most of the other creatures are attract and forget, which means you don't have to be particularly good at designing your dungeon. You just build things and wait.  Fights don't have a lot of strategy to them because all of the creatures feel the same. The ghost in DK1 for example, was a weak creature which could reflect magic and blow away enemies using wind, so you'd use that creature in certain situations. The bile demon was AOE, the warlock was ranged healing, the mistress was a kiter, the hellhound was for picking off runners and imps, the orc was a tank. There's not much of that here, you don't really need healers because you generally have so much mana that you can just heal creatures yourself. The creatures' offensive spells all feel the same. Everything feels bland and overpowered.  The lair and treasure room don't attract creatures and their shape doesn't matter, so you can just slap them down anywhere and forget about them. Boring. Make them do something.  The world map in DK1 was really cool, the way it was hand drawn and changed from good to evil over the course of the game. The one in this game isn't as interesting.  Still it's a good game and all but they need to take another look at DK1 instead of DK2 and see what made that game good.

A unique RTS that focuses on you building your dungeon and making sure its balanced, provides food, bed and other needs *cough*VAMPIRES*cough* for your army of minions. Sounds easy but as the difficulty ramps up and more is added to the mix you may end up with somthing like three of your own animated gold statues that you built and trained turning on you because you cant afford the gold to keep them running, oh yeah there are enemies too.  Its an RTS game with a twist. Your minions act however they see fit. You may influence their decision, but outside of the posession spell and the banner that says 'Attack Here' you and your opponent have little to no direct control of any outcome in this game.  For everyone who was a fan of the 2 dungeon keeper games this game is not only inspired by it but pays tribute to it many times, and thats just within the passive dialogue.   Great game, Every bit as good as its predecessors but with more stuff.  By the way. In this game. You are the bad guy. :)

After playing this game for about 10 hours, I feel I can write a faily solid review in relativity to the state the game is now in under release.   This game is a surprisingly amazing throwback and spiritual successor to Bullfrog's series Dungeon keeper. The gameplay is a breath of fresh air in an industry over saturated with Indie Devs creating stale replications of more popular games.  This game features dungeon building (which is amazingly satisfying), RTS elements. And economic balancing. Kind of a Towns/RTS if you will. The game features 4 modes, Campaign. Survival, Skirmish, and sandbox. (Multiplayer skirmish)   Campain acts as a story setting and tutorial for the game's research system, building and running your dungeon effectively. With brilliantly evil voice acting, fun and exciting missions that challenge your abilities as an Underlord. Campaign will keep you busy for hours and help you refine your skills as an underlord.  Skirmish is unfinished but the basic format for a skirmish game is 2 or more Underlords facing off in an attempt to destroy eachother's dungeon core (Larger player games are being worked on) This game gives you a fully unlocked Veins of evil tree to research the rooms nessesary to defeat the opposing player.  Survival is very much what is says on the box, and like skirmish, is still relatively under construction. Survival places you in a premade dungeon and gives you 3 lanes to defend where opposing heroes will try and breach your dungeon's defences and destroy your core. Sounds simple right? Its hard. Really hard. Good luck.  And sandbox, a dungeon building wonderland, where the game gives you the freedom to construct a dungeon of ludicrous size, and this mode, as free as it is, will only last you a certain amount of time, as the lack of enemy contact makes it feel.. empty at best after all of your rooms have been made.  At the time of review I can give this game my approval and definetly recommend this to any person who is a fan or the original Dungeon keeper series. And anyone who is a fan of RTS and 'Towns' Style games. But do not be afraid to try if you normally stray away from these styles of games! This game has somthing for everyone, and deserves as many sales as possible.  However, this game is still for the most part, an unfinished release and I have to deduct points for that. But the negatives far outweigh the positives in my eyes, and everyone should keep this game in mind, even if you don't plan on buying immediately post lauch. Please keep this in mind.  Credit is given where credit is due as Subterranean games breaths fresh life into a industry that is lacking new ideas recently (At least in my opinion) This game is a work of art and deserves your money.  I rate this game a solid 6/10 in its current state. I'm sure the score will rise to a 7/10 or a 8/10 in coming patches.  I have had tremendous fun so far with this game, and cannot wait for more content to arrive as Subterranean games have promised in free updates post launch. If you are looking for a solid throwback to Dungeon Keeper, and a great new IP to keep you busy for hours. War for the Overworld Certainly deserves to be a game in your library.

This isn't a finished game at launch. I'm sure it has every potential to be an amazing game, but right now, I could not recommend this. I genuinely wish I could say otherwise. Noteworthy is that the game is being patched incredibly quickly, so I would not be overtly pessimistic about the game.

i was a huge fan and put many hours into Dungeon Keeper. that being said.. i love what's been done so far, but MAJOR elements (imo) are still missing.   you need to be able to beat your minions into doing things they'd rather not.   you need to be able to lock them in a room and have them keep working in fear of more beatings, even as they starve to death. like a good minion should. it may seem harsh, but this is the mind set every good dungeon keeper should have.  i only got 4 stages or so in so far.. but none of my knocked out creatures are being dragged back to their beds to heal.   i can't toss creatures i don't want, right back out the way they came in.. in hopes of getting a different creature etc.  i can't hand feed those worthless little ♥♥♥♥♥ as a reward or to keep them working. i can't bribe them with riches either.  all in all though, i'm really glad this game was made.. though hoping certain things are added, i've had fun playing it.

I put off buying War For The Overworld for a very long time, principly because I believed there was no chance in hell it could live up to the legend that is Dungeon Keeper. I was sure it would just be a cheap imitation of a classic game with no original thought or work put into it, just ideas and concepts stolen from Dungeon Keeper, reskinned to look 'original' and packed into a half baked game not worth its price.  Holy ♥♥♥♥ was I wrong.  It's pretty damn great. Some minor problems concerning visual glitches and momentary freezes but otherwise it lives up to the reputation of Dungeon Keeper. The only major problem I have with War For The Overworld is how Mana works, I much preferred the mana system in Dungeon Keeper 2 where you are rewarded with a faster mana income from aggressive expansion but leave yourself vulnerable to attack. Sadly there is little strategical advantage you can get from amassing a large mana pool because there isn't a 'quick' way to get it.  The Developers clearly knew what they doing and what they aimmed to achieve with this game, and they succeeded in leaps and bounds. There's more than enough new concepts and game mechanics to make this title stand out from it's inspiration as a true spirital successor.  Well done.

Very happy with Dungeon Keeper Complete Edition aka 'War for the Overworld'. The original games had some clunky feeling to them that is all smoothed out in WftO. Voice acting sounds the same, units seem more responsive and there's more to do. With a couple patches and an expansion still coming out, this game is a full Early Access game success with backer promises being fulfilled and surpassed.  If you ever wanted to play Dungeon Keeper again, or if you ever missed out on the DK series (and I'm not including anything Electronic Arts poo'd out) then this is the game we've been given to replace that need.  Thanks Brightrock / Subterranean Games!

Still a bit rough, but it is WONDERFUL to be able to play. It is very much like Dungeon Keeper 2. I look forward to seeing the devs smooth out some things, and I really miss Horny. But I am quite happy with the game!

Like any Dungeon Keeper fanboy I was excited when news of this game reached my ears. Here was a promise to pay homage to a favorite game of mine from when I was way younger, a game that has had few of its like since it came out.  This is what I expected: A dungeon building simulator where you build your lair, gather minions, train them, build defenses and then storm the opposition. To say that this is not what I received would be a lie but the thing is the game delivers things so clunkily that all enjoyment is simply sucked out of it.   Yes, you do build your own fully functioning dungeon... assuming you can figure out the actual mechanics of the game, that being the logistics behind the rooms and how the minions interract with them. You can have lots of fun reading through half finished tool tips and placeholders and see if you can make sense of it.  You do employ a workforce of diabolical minions... but again the game is not exactly forthcoming on details on how they function inside your dungeon and in combat which leads to cluster♥♥♥♥ combat scenarios in which you just pile your guys together and hope they come out on top.  You do conquer realms and bring ruination to your enemies... but through a story that appears to be missing half of its cutscenes and animations and this is assuming that the game doesn't crash or go through constant memory leaks.  I guess you could say that this game delivers everything that was expected, but it is done so badly that all the fun gets lost behind somewhere. There's a lot of good ideas here but the game doesn't take its time to explain how they work and some ideas never get used at all.

Love this game, feels like the next 'Dungeon Keeper' which players of the originals will notice the little nods to its roots.  +Plenty of content +Home Realm (Build at your leisure and unleash waves of enemies) +Humor +Variant Underlords (Each once has a different look to it and the workers)  -Fast paced -Skirmish maps included are small -Short Campaign  This is a great game, but I spent alot of time playing DK1 and DK2, and the way WrtO differs seems to be in its pace, more so in skirmish against AI, the thing I enjoyed about DK was the slower pace, once you got past the tutorial levels you would normally start on one huge map which you had to spend time gathering gold and leveling up your minions, where as this one kinda forces you to play fast and with limited space, so theres no extravagant massive rooms you can build since you really need to use the space you have effectively.  The units themselves are very nicely done, but once again it lacks the content DK had, so if you dont know, on DK you had to manage your minions, and by this I mean there wasnt just a single minion per room so for instance in DK if you got a Fly and a Spider, you would normally have to try and keep them in seperate lairs because if they bump into once other when they arent training or using rooms they would attack and try to kill one another, this presenting a challenge if you wanted to keep both but served as something you really needed to keep an eye on, whereas in WftO there is just one type of minion per room and a empire version, none of your minions conflict everyone gets along very nicely.  Now the 'Vampire' unit I do like very much, having to keep a steady supply to keep them appeased and in return you get a very powerful unit, so here im going to refer to DK1 and you can proberly guess I mean the 'Horned Reaper' which was the games icon, which the Vampire unit itself is a nod to, both units need 3 units sacrificed to get one in return, whereas the vampire just needs food to stay happy, the Horned Reaper, well he was undeniably the strongest unit in the game but came with the biggest price, if you held him for to long he got ♥♥♥♥♥♥, if you slapped him he got ♥♥♥♥♥♥, if he was bored he got ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and he would begin slaughtering your own minions for the damn well fun of it, and a level 10 version of him would wipe out most of your minons, which would make you either decide on building a seperate mini-dungeon and lock him in it til you was ready to fight or having to get rid.  Refering to the pervious point there was the 'Temple' room, which you sacrificed units to make ones you needed or the Horned Reaper, but it served a second function, any creatures rebelling or Horned Reaper going on a rampage you could drop them on the outskirts of this room and they would pray and calm down over a period of time, now when they rebel in WftO you pretty much have to take them down, I could be wrong but at this present time I cant see anyway to calm them down, showered them with gold/food and they still wont revert from rebellion status.  All in all the thing about these games is feeling like the bad guy, and DK did that great, WftO goes down the same road but doesnt give me that 'Evil' vibe, aslong as you have food and gold, all your minions will hold hands and slip to battle, but here I am just remembering how much I loved DK, this game gets frequent patches and updates so who knows, maybe it will end up that way, but it is a great game and the closest ive seen to being a 'Dungeon Keeper' for a long time and is definatly worth playing, more so if you loved the DK games.   TL;DR  WftO is a great game, I ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about how much I miss 'Dungeon Keeper'. :D

The base game had a rocky start but has grabbed its rocks together and build a sturdy fort. Sure there are some things that do not go 100% from time to time as with every game. But this game seems to listen to its community and balance, patch issues out.  Having spend a fair load of time into the base game, i\'d rate it a 8/10 worthy of what it tried to achieve. And commendable concidering it was made by a ragtag of dungeonkeeper fans bundling their forces.

I'd recommend this if you were a fan of Dungeon Keeper. It's pretty much Dungeon Keeper with more features.  The only problem I have is you get interrupted SO OFTEN to get told what to do. If you are trying to watch Netflix or something while playing, don't bother because it will get talked over by non-notification dialogue ALL THE TIME. Diatrabe after diatrabe. On top of that you will get straight up forced to place certain things in certain places before you are able to use them anywhere else. You are even sometimes forced on a frozen screen while things are happening around you to perform certain actions. I got slid over to a room as I was about to give a dig command and it caused me to accidentally set a dig command on one of my outer walls that I could not undo because I was frozen on the other room until I finished the task.  It's a lot of very forced and heavy handed tutorial style tasks that I would absolutely love if you could turn off, but I'm not holding it against the game because even though I'm 5 missions in and they are still doing it I am really hoping that they knock it off sometime soon.

Game has a lot of potential, but still a very unpolished game (Multiplayer not working, debugging tooltips, framerate drops), and doesnt follow my defition of done, when you release something.   If you're a DK1 and 2 diehard fan, you can most likely ignore these flaws (Like me)  If you're not, give it a patch or two before you buy it, mostly because it isnt done yet. Properly gonna be epic by then.
'Dungeon Keeper with upgraded graphics and a skill tree'. Seriously. Thumbs up though, because hey, more Dungeon Keeper!

This game has a lot of potential, but in no way it is ready to be released. As much as I love DK series and this being a spiritual successor of it, I absolutely cannot recommend this game to anyone until it is at least playable. I remember playing an earlier release, and I thought that with the newest patches, at least some of the game breaking issues were fixed. On the contrary, new issues have been introduced. This time I cannot scroll left or right, so I have to use the silly WASD to move around the map. Some cutscenes freeze, such as the one about shifting bond in the fifth level and disable scrolling altogether. Have you guys actually tested scrolling? Was this part of your QA items at all??? Shame on you for using paying users as testers where it should have been your job in the first place. At least now textures do not flicker when you reload the game and the gameplay does not come to a grinding halt. Please test your product before releasing it.

If you loved DK2, u ll love this one as well. but the game right now isn't ready!!! so many bugs. if you can wait, wait. if you know for sure you want to play with it, than why not buy it now. just be prepared for the bugs.

Patches are being made left, right and centre. Definitely recommend the game for the people wanting to buy it, still a few small bugs, but personally I can deal with that. The devs are keeping up with the demands for sure, great job guys.
Dungeon Keeper 3, plain and simple.  The old formula with very little changed and updated with more modern polygonal graphics.  Can't go wrong, highly recommend.
Fantastic succesor to the Dungeon Keeper franchise that has improved immensely since its launch to lackluster reception.

While I generally think this game is a thumbs up, I can't say I am entirely happy with the level of polish... or lack there of.  It truly feels like a sequel or spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2, but seems to lack a little of the heart that went into that title. It has a similar sense of humor, but maybe a bit more drab than the old DK franchise. I can see that the devs loved DK and wanted to make this as close to that concept as possible, but in too many places it falls just shy of the potential.  The old Dungeon Keeper games had some bad bugs in them that made them almost inplayable at times and unfortunately this game does follow that same trend as well. That being said, the devs have not given up on this game and appear to be trying to fix, improve, and expand on the game months after it's full release, so here is to hoping this game gets enough love from both players and devs over time.  All said, it does feel like Dungeon Keeper 2.5... I just wish it had felt more like Dungeon Keeper 3. But still a fun game and if you want to try something new or something old that feels new again, give this game a try. Worth a play.

I played the campaign it took me 20 hours. I found no reason to keep playing after that but I really enjoyed that time. If it's on sale buy it; If it isn't and you have nothing else you want to play at a lower price I think it's still worth it.

Had this in my wishlist ever since I heard news of the game that was suppose to be a follow up to DK. Decided to give it a try and wow I was not dissapointed. I feel the state of the game is great. There was no bugs that I ran into while casually playing the game which from previous comments during first release seemed to be many but they all seemed to be patched (Thank you developers and community for this). I was afraid that the game would just be some cheap attempt to remake this game that I loved so much but the developers have really gone above and beyond to make it feel like DK with the voice acting and humor. Definietly did not regret spending the dough for this game, I cannot wait to finish the campaign and whatever else they have in store!

If you liked Dungeon keeper, this is essentially and updated version of it. Great purchase for scratching your evil overlord itch. Good value, good design, good graphics. Now laugh like a maniac and buy it.

Where do I start with this game? Ahh, yes... YOU ARE AN EVIL GOD! One of the best RTSs that I have ever played. Everyone has a secret evil side, some less secret than others... but that doesn't matter, AS LONG AS I GET TO HEAR THE PAINED CRIES OF MY ENEMIES AS MY MINIONS SLAUGHTER THEM ALL! The narrator is definitely my favorite character, he is hilarious. The best part of this game, besides being evil, is that it is an RTS that feels like it isn't an RTS, you actually have minions that need taking care of, they eat, drink, sleep, work, fight, and get paid (and get tortured). You literally have to control your own society, while fighting the empire. Plus, in my opinion the campaign gets incredibly difficult as you get to Mira's Dungeon. I will not inform you who Mira is, because that could be a spoiler. There is really only one thing that I don't like. Every other Underlord is completely useless, they don't do anything except mutter giberish. I won't get into too much detail as that could also be a spoiler. Overall 9/10.
Nice game, lots of fun for a few hours. More contents would be great. The narrator is really lame. He sounds lame and what he says is actually very lame.  6.5/10
just like dungeon keep 2 with more thing they add.

For me this is a game still in development, the ending of the campaign is very confusing, to the point it is either really bad or its a, to be continued.   However, the game is easy (still trying to complete DK 1) and I was able to complete each level up to level 10 first time and the final level. 11 and 12 took many many attempts.   It has the feel of DK series but the humour is not as good. I was playing to 4AM one night and it did not tell me to go to bed or that my imps did an impression of me.   The voice of the narrator is the same but not in the same style. This is not DK 3 but it is a good modern DK style game.   I have only played campaign and felt this was quick to play and the ending needs something doing to it but I enjoyed it. For £14 it was good, full price, no. I am glad I waited for this release than the early access and can say it worked on my laptop and desktop with only a little stuttering on the laptop (Win 8 integrated chip graphics).   Work on the ending lads, I mean complete it, and if it is to be completed by DLC, think about how you will finish it and the cost as at mo, the game at full price.....is not good.  Further, Nice work so far lads, looking forward to your future work.

First of all I'd like to say - IGNORE THE METACRITIC SCORE!!!! It's only the score that it is because people started leaving reviews before the game was finished and before the 1.1 patch was released. This patch has been a complete revelation!  I know what many of you are probably thinking as you trawl through the reviews left for War for the Overworld......'I thoroughly enjoyed the Dungeon Keeper games and I'd really hope that War for the Overworld would live up to my expectations, given that it's not exactly cheap'. Well, as a long term Dungeon Keeper fan (I'm 28 now and played it daily when i was a teen, including a few play throughs as I've gotten older), I can assure you that you won't be disappointed.   I actually felt quite sceptical when purchasing this game, simply because I enjoyed the original Dungeon Keepers games so much. I often hype up something in my own mind to the point where it will probably disappoint, but I've been very pleasantly surprised.   This is about as close as you can get to a Dungeon Keeper 3. I think the creators have done a really great job of keeping just enough of the old Dungeon Keeper vibes to satisfy the DK fans (for example the resemblance of many of the units in the game - The 'Workers' are clearly Imps, the 'Chunders' who love to work in the workshop and have the ability to 'fart' as a weapon (much like my girlfriend) are Bile Demons and you also get a female unit that loves to torture your enemies in the torture chamber.....remind you of anything (except without my old favourite spell lightning).   Your creatures still need to eat but have moved away from chickens and now prefer micropiglets, and some of your old favourite spells are still available like being able to create more workers, being able to reveal parts of the map for limited time, and also the 'Call to Arms' spell has a 'Rally' option too.   I think what's really great about War for the Overworld is the fact that the developers etc have taken great care to only change or remove elements from the DK games that actually work to improve this game. Does anyone remember in Dungeon Keeper how if you had enough gold, you could build an unlimited amount of traps and doors all over your dungeon, while you sat back and used the sight of evil spell in conjunction with the lightening or cave in spells to kill all of the enemy units? yeh you can'y do that anymore, you now actually have to think a bit more and strategy plays more of a part. Your mana pool is actually now split between the number of workers you have, the number of traps you have and any spells that you wish to cast. This means that you have to find a balance between those things because you have loads of workers, you wont be able to lay any traps or cast any spells, alternatively if you have loads of traps, you won't be able to create many extra workers or cast many spells. This was a welcome addition to the game because it's makes things more challenging, but not too difficult.   The graphics are nice and crisp, even if the frame rate can take an occasional hit on a very busy map (nothing that'd bothered me too much mind), the sound effects are very good and actually quite funny in terms of the things you hear your creatures randomly say, and there's more than enough content to keep you playing for a while with multiplayer, the campaign and a survival type mode.   Overall I've been really, pleasantly surprised by this game and what I also think is great is that the developers are really looking after it when it comes to releases/patches/updates. They regularly make sure that they respond to requests from people in terms of improvements etc and they aren't just light touches either. When i first got the game, I felt a little sad that your workers aren't able to level up. After a few days they'd released another couple of updates which added the ability for workers to level and i noticed they'd fixed EVERY other minor bug that I'd experienced.   You get exactly what you'd want and would expect from this game and the aftercare provided by the regular updates etc. It's fun, challenging, addictive and you still get to feel very nostalgic if you loved the original Dungeon Keeper games. If you never played those games and are instead just contemplating buying this game - do it, you won't regret it.   Graphics - 8/10 (for what it is, i think they're great)  Sound - 9.5/10  Gameplay 9/10 (With several game modes and the fact that each time you play you can change your style - you'll come back to this time anbd time again)  Overall - 9/10

The Good:  Great game, just like a modern remake of dungeon keeper 2 with a few added features.    The Bad:  Doesn't support AMD Crossfire. Cranking the graphics to the max does put the strain on my r9 290x, but I have a 2nd one just sitting there idling.

The game will be less buggy and polished soon, and no one else has stepped up to the challenge of bringing back bullfrogs dungeon keeper (save the abhorrent mobile game from EA who murder bullfrog productions) so for me STG has sparked a childhood dream for me and it will be visible to others very soon  id like to add that STG has realesed around 13 patches in three days, how many devs can u think of who work that hard?

So first off: There are al lot of bugs and a horrible UI yeah. But this game and the people creating it are not comparable to EA or UBI as really big developers. You have to rate the process of this game just different then when it would be released by the two companies mentioned. It feels like Dungeon Keeper and this is something a lot of games wanted to accomplish but never did it. The engine itself (Unity) is still not very well performing on some systems yeah. But when i purchased this game in Alpha-Stage then there a huge steps and good steps forward since then. Sure it was a failure to release this version this early as 1.0 final build but guys... People who are creating this game are more like people like me and you are, so just give it a little more time and be patient. If they keep up the quality and speed of improving this game, then ill be sure this is the new dungeon keeper we all wished for. Just be fair and supportive, they deserve it.

War for the Overworld is the closest game you'll get to Dungeon Keeper 3, until EA decide to do something great with the property.  It shares many similarities to the classic Bullfrog games, but with a lot of bells and whistles (spells, potions, devices etc), giving the game depth and better control over your army. If you want to play a great 'Dungeon Keeper' then you'll love this game. The humour is there, possession, torture chambers, workers -- everything you loved.  The campaign is pretty good. *Most* of the missions were fun, but some were either too easy, or boring. I don't think it reached the quality of the Bullfrog titles unfortunately.  Pet Dungeon seems pointless without the ability to spawn enemies.   Skirmish and multiplayer are fun, thanks to the SIn ( level-up ) system, that gives you different ways to play and try out. Imagine a RPG tree system for your rooms and abilities.  Some technical problems; nothing game breaking, or causing the game to crash, but you might see weird stuff happen occasionally.  If you want another Dungeon Keeper experience then buy it and enjoy. If you want a strategy game, you might find the games rough points distracting.
The one Dungeon Keeper-esque game released since Bullfrog that actually delivers. This IS the DK3 we've been waiting for, and I hope EA chokes on the sales and praise this game rightfully deserves.

So you design your own dungeon and if the little pissants won't do as you'd like you can jump in them and 1st person force them to your will. An amazing rework of the old Dungeon Keeper 2. Story is great and comical.
After a rough start, this game is now playable. Though it still lacks a proper My Pet Dungeon mode, it otherwise feels exactly like Dungeon Keeper 2. Addendum: Map editor is fun.
If this is similar to Dungeon keeper, I now understand the love the thing gets.

One campaign, a look through the level editor and a rapid check of the multiplayer later, can I truly give this game a honest review ? Oberon help me, let's do this.  WFTO is a labour of love, a game that was born from passion rather than a desire for money.It is the kind of experience that might be less polished than other games (the game could use a ton of bugfixes), but every inch of the game has been crafted with passion, and you've got to respect that. But there's a lot to say about this spiritual sequel to Dungeon Keeper.  Graphically, the game is superb, and more importantly, it's  memorable !  From the colorful rooms, to the dark creatures, down to the little details like the awesome logo (can't keep my eyes off that logo, it's pretty !) or the achievement icons, this games looks great. Kudos to the art team.  Musically there isn't much to discuss, the music is very discrete, but the sound design and narrator voice more than make up for that silence. Too bad after 20 hours all I wanted was for him to shut up, because he never stops talking.   Campaign is solid, a good tutorial that suffers from some ridiculous difficulty spikes at times. I rage quit some missions multiple times because some rival underlord's actions are very random and they won't behave the same way every time.  In the end, this game could potentially become a worthy successor to DK/DK2, but it still needs some fine tuning and polishing. In terms of content, there's more than enough to keep you busy for months, but I don't really feel compelled to return now that i have finished the campaign (which is still something only 10% of the playerbase has done, so hurray !).  Wait for the developers to iron out most problems, wait for it to go on sale, and grab yourself a copy of War for the Overworld.

I've been following this game since it was announced but I can now say that the current build is polished and a suitable successor to the Dungeon Keeper games.   Bloodstained ne'er-do-wells and bucket loads of nostalgia...

For people who know (and love) Dungeon Keeper:  WFTO is in my opinion the first worthy sequel to the DK-games from Bullfrog, BUT it is A LOT like DK2... the gaming-feeling is almost the same and the rooms arent very different. I personaly prefered DK1 over DK2 and therefore my expections where maybe a little high, cause I waited about 12 year for a game like this. But like I marked, i recommend this game. because it is still a really good game (like the DK1/2 where long before) and i have to admit, that there were some good and new ideas, which improved gameplay a litte (like the 'replacement earth' construct, which allows you to add a tile of normal earth, which is a dream for perfectionist like me). I have stil one thing to complain about: the campaign is WAY too short!! 12 lvls... c'mon... for experienced players it will take you about 10-15h...

So, some mixed feelings on this one.   It doesn't drop the ball hard and it had the potential to. There have been a lot of attempts at making games like Dungeon Keeper and many of them failed. War for the Overworld doesn't fail so much as I feel like they could have done more.  Mostly, the campaign is a bit short. Took me 20 hours and a lot of that was me choosing to make things harder for myself than I had to. Ending is a bit weird, but seems like they're setting themselves up for DLC.

The game is pretty good, I really recommend it. Because the game has like alot of features, and once you complete Campaign, you can also play with bots in skrimish mode, or go to sandbox to play some certain developer-made scenarios and maps with no objectives. Play with your friends or other people in multiplayer, and dominate them with your Dungeon core skills. And play survival mode which is still a prototype. This game is really good. The only problem I have with this game is the AI, if your aren't ust to strategy games, you'll have lots of issues with the AI, but when you've been playing strategy games and other type of games that are similar will have entertained for hours, days and even months. Overall, this game is fantastic!
its a worthy replacement for dk!

Are all the reviews putting it alongside Dungeon Keeper? Yes. Is it quite Dungeon Keeper? No. Is it really close? Yes. Is it ultimaltely what a DK fan is looking for? 90%, says I. From the narrator's voice to the trap placement to the 'similar but not identical' rooms and monsters, this is the only game I know of that comes anywhere close, and it's damn close. Do it.
I enjoyed a similar game when i was younger. I enjoyed this game just as much. i would reccomend it if you have played a similar game from the 90s.

I did not play this game in Early Access. My impression is based on the current release. This game has everything I loved about the Dungeon Keeper series and has its own take on things like skilltrees for unlocking building/spells. Yes, you still can possess minions in this 'spiritual successor' and take first-person control over them. The building-your-own-dungeon aspect will be familiar to anyone who has played the series this game is inspired by.  The finishing touch is Richard Ridings and the excellent narration that gave the original Dungeon Keeper its charm.   I haven't played much of this game so far, but I'm 100% enjoying it. If you're looking for a modernized take on Dungeon Keeper this one is a buy.
an allright game similar to DK but when 50 creatures are on the map it laggs like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥...

i love this. it reminds me of my childhood favorite game dungeon keeper. i don't believe its made by any of the people who worked on dungeon keeper but it reminds me so much of it. i love it. games like this are very few and far apart, i give it a 9/10. heres why  this is one of the few games where you play as the bad guy. its a RTS that takes place in dungeons. you build facilities for your creatures, you feed them, train them, and in return they will defend your dungeon, attack another enemy keeper, attack heroes, research things like rooms, spells and traps. finally they will also do things like convert captured enemies, and make traps. sounds a little complicated but like the DK games, they slowly walk you through it. anyhow i love it, its more or less a blast from the early/mid 90s, remade for today and i would love to see more games like this
If you even remotely liked Dungeon Keeper or Dungeon Keeper 2 you'll love this. So much nostalgia!

I was one of the original backers from the Kickstarter and am satisified with my purchase for now, the Devs might have rushed this title out a little prematurely but at least the campaign feels right. Playing through the campaign is like going back to the 90s and experiencing Dungeon Keeper in all its glory.  If you are looking for Dungeon Keeper 3 this is the closest thing you will find on the market period, they have the exact same guy from DK 1 and 2 doing the voices. This company will work hard to squash bugs and to expand this game you can guarantee it.

This game has come a long way in the years since I played the original early access alpha. I replayed the game a few times as it was updated to get a feel for how it was progressing, and I must say I am quite impressed with the state the game is in now compared with just 6 months ago. The game is well balanced and the progression is smooth from start to finish on the campaign (and in a skirmish). It's not just feature complete but feature rich.... way more content than ANY Dungeon Keeper game ever made. And from what I understand they have plans to add even more content soon with no signs of stopping! It's almost kind of ridiculous how much work has been put into this game. The personality of the original Dungeon Keeper games is intact and further refined. This game makes me laugh out loud regularly! If you were a fan of the original Dungeon Keeper games, this game could become an obsession for you. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECCOMEND!
i played this game for hours loving every bit if you are a dungeon keeper fan this is the game for you!

this game is really cool its almost exactly like dungeon keeper 2. the problem is that it runs really laggy yeah my cpu isn't the best but i only played 17 hours trying to fix the speed issues and no refund is availiable, that sucks. be extra sure your cpu has lots of memory before you get this game

Really enjoying this game as I played Dungeon Keeper 2. It very much feels like the sequel. The bugs and problems stated in the negative reviews seem to be mostly fixed. Only a few glitches have I encountered and not a single one was game shattering (only minor things such as after using an archon ability during possession, you can't move).
9/10, would give it 10/10 but i want to see more campaign! It's everything I hoped it could be back in bedrock beta. Hats of to the Devs :)

Although I haven't played all that much of this game yet, due to being overly addicted to Don't Starve, I still have adored the parts that I have played. This game is blatantly the remastered version of the Dungeon Keeper series (which is an awesome franchise). You start as a newly awoken 'Underlord' (They didn't want to rip off the Overlord series). As the dungeon master, you must build and slaughter your way through the underground realms, to take over the surface. I may add more to this review once I have played more of it, but the only problem I have is the difficulty. Even in the early game, the gameplay is brutal. If you're new to the Dungeon Keeper games, I expect you will struggle a lot. Apart from that, get this game, you will (probably) not be disappointed.  Highly recommended - 8.5/10

It's ok. You know... in the way a nice piece of fresh bread is ok, or a sort of decent hot chocolate. It's not great, like a BJ from Abbie in the bushes behind the oval in high school, or an 21 year old single malt whiskey. It's fun, just don't expect it to rock your world. I question whether it's the best value out there though - at this price point you can find games a lot more engaging, but it's alright.  I'm not going to bother writing about the game specifics. I often do, but there are plenty of other reviews that are already doing thatn. Read them. I never said this was a GREAT review...
I loved Dungeon Keeper 1 & 2, and I love this game!
Of course the DK classic first is still the best but this works too, I guess.

This is the game all Dungeon Keeper Fans have been waiting for!  I must admit from when i first bought the game back in 2014 till now it has come a really long way and although there are aspects that still dont work such as multiplayer the gameplay itself is fantastic. I highly reccommend this to anyone who loved the origional dungeon keeper series.  Do support the development team, there are a few bugs at the moment but i know they are working extremely hard to patch them as quickly as possible. Keep up the great work guys.
Very good spiritual successor to DK, very polished and fun. However, the game is very laggy. It's running at 60 FPS, but there's a huge input lag - both for mouse and keyboard.
Patches have really made this game great. A good throw back too Dungeon Keeper.

I've had this game for quite a while, back then it was still the bedrock beta. Now how-ever, it is out of beta and the full release is here. I must say I really enjoy this game.  Unfortunately at release after delays it still wasnt ready. It's still playable and thoroughly enjoyable. The Dev's are dishing out patches that fix these bugs though NON-STOP, they are very dedicated to this game.  Bugs and glitches aside, this game is definitely worth the price and a blast, and once patched up will be phenomenal. I highly recommend you play this game. If not now to avoid bugs and glitches, then definitely later. You wont regret it.  Best Dungeon Keeper Simulator 2015.
Very similar to the great franchise that was Bullfrog's Dungeon Keeper until it was shut down by Electronic Arts. A worthy addition to the series.

When I first purchased this game I had little hopes of it ever becoming a complete game with a full campaign. Honestly I hadn't even had it installed beyond the point of the first couple weeks. Recently I have been pleasantly surprised. Not only has the game been given a campaign with a decent story but it did an excellent job leaving us off for further story (which I hope is on its way) Hours of great game play, good story, versatility and control over your dungeons population, a wide varriety of creatures, spells, defenses and rooms. lastly, a mode in which you can personally challenge yourself after you have beaten the story of the current game.   Cons   - Whan your dungeon population starts getting a bit higher the game starts running a touch clunky (my pc specs are pretty decent)   - Units will sometimes get stuck on the edges objects in a room. This does not occur often enough for it to cause any considerable grief.  Fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed DK2 in years passed.

I like how Richard Ridings returned as the dungeon mentor and it returned with telling us we should be asleep when it is a specific time. Now I do recommend this game, for the moment, for those who mainly just want to experience Dungeon Keeper again. However, no game is complete w/ out bugs. Don't worry, you get plenty of them hiding around the corner. And no game is complete w/ out flaws as well. That being the minimap. It tends to be hard to figure out where the enemies are coming from if you have a hard time seeing their position on the minimap. When the dungeon mentor doesn't say anything it makes it harder. There are only 3 skirmish maps and both are small (only 2 players per map). And I don't know if anyone else ha a problem with it but I personally feel there are too many gold tiles and many of which are in large chunks and appear too often in unconvenient spots so it seems as though the game is trying to force you to stick with 3x3 rooms or have a dungeon thats just one big cluster ♥♥♥♥ of rooms that aren't separated. I like to build larger rooms to spawn more minions from that room rather than having to keep building the same room over and over. If you can look pass the flaws of the game, then I would recommend it. If you can't... well... come back later.
Excellent Game, though some bugs are still being ironed out.
Played through a few times while still in Early Access. It was a little light on depth and strategy for a game like this, but ultimately this was a solid purchase as a big fan of sim and RTS games
Great game with more depth in gameplay than DK2. Also it is in a good state right now and has many hours of playtime available due to campaign and skirmish battles.
very good game like dungen keeper 1 & 2 makes fun to play!  a few things still missing but the developers are very good! I'm looking forward to the updates in the coming weeks

True successor to DK2. I waited it out as when this first appeared on here it was in very early development and I'd rather just play a full game.   Now that wait is over, and after playing it for a bit, I'm impressed with what I've seen so far. I want to thank the devs for giving us this, because it's the closest thing we'll ever get to DK3 and they have pulled it off more than I could ever have hoped for.
the successor to dungeon keeper 2

A fantastic game that is extremely fun. It's a very good representation of the old Dungeon Keeper games. It launched unfinished and lacking polish, but it's been given a lot of love and care that it needed.   Would highly reccomend to anyone interested in a Dungeon Keeper style game
Love it. With the newest patches things seem to be okay stable and playable.
Honestly the true succeser to DK After a slightly rocly alpha release i opened up this game to find it is everything i ever wanted it to be. Faith restored.

Review with v1.3  I am a bit sad to give a negative review on this one, I can feel the love of the Dungeon Keeper saga by the dev team, every aspect of the game remind you his ancestor, but the technical aspect is a mess and ruin the experience. 2.5/5 My advice is to wait  Good:  -same voice acting as the original saga -campaign is a bit dull but represents a good introduction to the new mechanics -IA is tough to beat on skirmish -feels like DK 2.5  Bad -... but it's not DK3 -poor perfomance even on a good PC (suttering if not on a SSD, fps drop a lot even with a GTX980 4G) -not pretty nore oringinal graphics -Price is not representing the value of this software.
Really fun game and you get the real feeling from DK series, recommend!

Is there anything more to say? Dungeon Keeper on steroids. WHO WOULDN'T WANT THAT DOESN'T HAVE A LIFE! 11/10  Okay now a serious review:  This game is amazing, it has every bit of dungeon keeper with better graphics, and small, minor enchancements to the gameplay which can't be called gamebreaking. Excellent job at balancing out this game so nicely. It has everything a dungeon keeper fan could want. ONCE AGAIN 11/10 !

This is a game where I wish Steam would have a third recommendation option (other than just yes or no) because my main recommendation is to play Dungeon Keeper 2 instead. WfTO is more or less what the developers wanted it to be, an homage to Dungeon Keeper. This game matches the gameplay and the environment very well. If you are tired of playing DK2, but still want to experience more of that gameplay, than I would recommend this game to you. However, if you are looking for even a tiny amount of freshness in this genre, I cannot recommend this game.

This game was released to soon as the unfinished product, it should be still in EARLY ACCESS! Tons of bugs, crashes, placeholders, unfinished features, multiplayer pretty messy. Stay away from this mess until few months

I7 / 16 g ram / 2tb HDD / 4 g vid.  The origional Dungeon Keeper game rocked, the expansion pack Deeper Dungeons rocked.  DK2 was a graphic upgrade.   This chapter is a graphic upgrade as well. This game gets a thumbs up from me. It's the closest thing to a Dungeon Keeper remake that we can hope for.  I do miss the old creatures and heroes from Dungeon Keeper. I don't know why but I prefer generic and recognizable monsters like goblins, trolls, and hero parties with the likes of knights, wizards and elves. In this game you have units with similar roles but different names and skins (Gnarling = Goblin, for example). The result is a bit of a weird exotic mix of creatures and heroes made up by the dev team. I suspect that this has something to do with copy right issues which make too many similarities with Dungeon Keeper a legal risk. I hope maybe one day there will be a mod with some of the creatures from the old games.  Though I'm not a fan of the unit and hero roster I did notice and greatly appreciate that units that you corrupt (convert via torture chamber) actually change their appearance and dialogue. Dungeon Keeper did not give me that.  The gameplay itself is honestly an improvement over Dungeon Keeper 2, and that is high praise indeed! Your minions are much more logically classified as either 'beasts' or 'intelligent'. So no more facepalm when I see animals drinking at tables or gambling away money... Only intelligent creatures get gold payments and can do research for example. On the other hand beasts eat much more food and require different approaches to training and separate lairs. I also like the addition of an alchemy room for potion making, but I'm sad to see no equivalent for the dark temple or my favorite: the graveyard.  There are also some very neat additions. One of the biggest frustrations I had with the original dungeon keeper games was that they didn't let me fill in areas with dirt. In this game you can for a little bit of gold.  Overall I'd recommend this game!

Do you remember Dungeon Keeper 2? You  did  like it right? Well there's nothing else to say then, for the remaining people, continue reading. War for the Overworld is a RTS game which puts you in the shoes of an Underlord: a mystical being which has the power of creating dungeons and using the forces of evil (minions and so...). The purpose of the game itself is to build your own dungeon, and that's where all the fun lies. Many Underlords prefer building traps, other train their creatures to death in order to slay enemies, others use a mixture of both. While doing so you also know how to use some magic that can help your cause. To build your dungeon you have workes to help you, just tell them where to dig, what to do and they will without fail. By creating space you can start build rooms that will attract creatures to your dungeon. Pretty interesting right? Well, the campaign is well done but incosistent: some moments are far too easy and some other are hell itself. I haven't yet tried the multiplayer, but the game is actively developed and I think there will be many interesting suprises with time. A game worth its money.

This game, an obvious copycat of Dungeon Keeper (and that's not a bad thing), is very much like a disorienting disco where too many hallucinogens have throttled the experience from the mundane to the overwhelming. It's not that this game is bad. Actually, if they corrected a few mistakes, this game could be very cool. Unfortunately, the couple of problems that this game has makes for a disorienting and annoying experience.   First, the color palette is inappropriate to the genre, and, additionally, it is distracting to they eye. Let's face it, dungeons are dark places that are lit by torches. Fluorescent greens, oranges, and yellows do not belong in dungeons, except in the rare circumstance where magic is present. Most of the time, dungeons are like dungeons. That is, they are cold, dark, and earthy. Just looking at this game for too long can burn your retinas. I advise against that.  Second, the camera control is very limited. I want to be able to get a greater view of the happenings in my dungeon, dammit. Making me stay stay close in scope in relation to the goings on in my dungeon makes me dissatisfied. I'm the CEO of the dungeon, right? Shouldn't I be able to see the greater picture?  Like I said. I don't think this is a bad game, but it lacks insight into the basic wants of the RTS gamer.

This game could be ok, however, the controls are seriously lacking. Simple things like controlling and keeping track of your minions are difficult if not impossible.   The camera is too close to the ground imo preventing a decent god's eye view (Your are a god or demon lord right?)  Some of this could easily be fixed by adding a way to view warbands and who is in them. The mechanics of how the warbands work and rally points work is not obvious.  I like the concept and want to like the game, but after playing for a few hours, I can't get into it due to the chaos of attempting to manage my army.

While I do enjoy this game I must give it a thumbs down because while this game looks like Dungeon Keeper... it is not Dungeon keeper. While this game has all the trappings of DK series, the goofy monsters, the dungeon building, the game voice narrirator, this is not a true DK3.  The glaring difference between this and the previous 2 DK games comes in the level of level creativity and ability to explore. This game quickly becomes a giant dogpile of troops rushing to the end. It lacks the exploration element in DK 1&2 that are so essential to the overall feel of the game. The zerg rush of the game gets so bad that rooms like the workshop are utterly useless. You can't build doors and traps because you are constantly summoning your monsters to engage the enemy or rush the end lair. You can't take any time because the AI is too agressive or the level is under a timer. Unlike the games predecessors that allowed you to meticulously plot your dungeon, explore every nook and crany for all the secrets and craft the army you want you are in an RTS scramble to build as quickly as you possibly can and that saps alot of the enjoyment out of the game.  I hope that if they release DLC (a 2nd campaign) the creators really sit back and change the whole tempo of the game. While the game looks like Dungeon Keeper it plays more like the Warcraft franchise. If I wanted to play Warcraft/Starcraft I would have picked that up instead of DK3.

I honestly don't know if I can recommend this game in it's current state. the gameplay was good. very reminiscent of the Dungeon Keeper games, with a few bits added in, and of course a few bits taken away - and many that directly mirror the games themselves with renames or reskins, the campaign obviously wasn't as long, about 13 levels compared to DK2's 18. The narrator doesn't an excellent job, but there's minimal cutscenes, and what bothers me the most is the performance issues and bugginess of the game - several missions I retried because my game crashed so many times, and often saves would corrupt and you'd have to start anew. This was more of an issue on the last handful of missions where levels were much longer.  In terms of difficulty I can't really say I struggled at all, the A.I. are particularly lassaiz faire, with the exception of Level 12 where you fight 3 'underlords' (referring back to a very similar mission in DK2, but their dungeon structure followed a straightforward pattern that I noticed very quickly (playing the level several times due to crashing and admittedly 1 or 2 restarts), however the last mission is very lacklustre, the enemy has a big base, but they throw very small raiding parties at you of size between 8 and 12 creatures of levels 6+, which is basically just a level farm for your minions, and you can attack whenever ready. The last mission was very glitchy though - loading in from a save just before a defeat (I was attacking and didn't notice a party) there were creature models missing, and the drawbridge was invisible. Also the ending is complete and utter bullcrap.  Aside from this, the gameplay was fun, I did enjoy it as I love RTSs and it also had funny moments. I have yet to play any other modes or skirmishes but it was a shame that it's so buggy.

Brilliantly executet 'reverse' strategy game.   You're also the bad guy. No moral dillema, grey area, anything like that. You're straight up the big bad evil guy.  Also it runs great. I haven't found any outstanding bugs besides a few minions getting stuck here or there but that can be fixed quickly with a slap or a pick up.
Really enjoying this, a great update on the dungeon keeper formula. Devs are still patching the game and adding new features.

UPDATED: When I first bought this game, I suffered a bug, well, many bugs just getting the game working. The resolution did not want to change, and the largest offender of them all, was that in a Dungeon Keeper-esque game, the ability to dig tiles was impossible. There was no mouse control in game except for the UI, and that is the most infurating thing possible.  However, War for the Overworld seems to have a very dedicated Developer, and thier team found a workaround to my problem(Look at the comments for details).  The Gameplay is pretty fun, and the theme does not detract from the game at all. Building is a snap, researching is as well. If I had any real complaints, it's the speed is fast, faster then I am used to, but this just serves as a additional challenge.  Definitely pick this up if you want a compentent modern take on Dungeon Keeper. Just be careful of the bugs.
The game everybody was waiting for since Dungeon Keeper 2!  And not a single bug, or glitch so far.
the game is superb but the fps drops are just to consitent   and i have a top end pc

Love it! Very faithful to the previous DK games.

Great game, just like the last 2 Dungeon Keeper games. Not much more to say, if you like RTS games and a little bit of evil comedy, then this is one for you.
It has been fixed with one of the recent patches, not sure which one fixed it, but I won't complain. I've been enjoying it so far and looking forward to putting in some more hours.
great game, just like dungeon keeper. alot easier though.

Really good rework of the old Dungeon Keeper 2, I used to play that game a lot and this game has really brought those memories back while also adding some amazing new feature that also fit in. The campaign is pretty cool, they made some levels with very interesting mechanics that differ from how you usually play the game which they should explore and adapt a bit more. The levels where you play with or against other Underlords were also really fun, I feel like they could've used those characters more in other levels though, makes it less lonely when it's just you versus the empire.  The expansion was a bit dissapointing seeing as the campaign was a bit dull with a few funny parts here and there, however it's a free expansion so there are no issues there.

This is a great game to play through once. I've almost finished the campaign, and it's a fun story. I love that this is a spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2, but find myself wishing there was less going on. I tend to never use certain pieces of the game like potions, and rarely even fortifications. It's easier to knock all the walls down, build big rooms, and then place the rally banner on the enemy and throw heals/lightnings down.  There's a lot of breadth here - but I wish there was more depth. I do recommend the game, but it's so frantic I never feel like I get to experience everything the game offers.

You should ignore the bad comments.  After ending the first campaign (did not start Heart of Gold yet) i can safely say that this is confirmed a 'sequel' of Dungeon Keeper, with it's own unique characteristics, even the main voice actor is the same Richard Ridings, had a lot of fun.  I've seen some crying about the gold shrines,   that provide infinite money  , i'd say this is a cool thing, as most maps objectives aren't about wealth management.  Tons of improvements and new/different things that made the game even better, if you are a true fan of Dungeon Keeper and do enjoy new things you must try this.  About the graphics, sometimes when the map is big it can lag a little, i am running a GeForce 960 on maximum quality graphics and sometimes it lagged a little.  Yes the game does not require much of strategy, it is, overall, an easy but fun game.  Buy it already.  Tips: - Press 0 (zero) to send all units to someplace - Press Alt + 0 (zero) to recall all units

A very, -very- unenthusiastic recommendation. In theory, WFTO has all the right pieces to be a Dungeon Keeper successor, but it's lacking.... something. It's difficult to put my finger on it, but after going through the campaign I was less than impressed. It's missing that bit of charm that DK had for itself. Maybe it's because the campaign feels like it's just a long tutorial for each of the rooms and traps and ends suddenly without letting you enjoy your fully-unlocked tech tree.  That's not to say the game isn't good, though. It does very interesting things with rooms that DK 1 and 2 didn't, such as giving the 'props' in rooms an efficiency bonus for being near fortified walls. It's a mixed bag, though; rooms larger than 5x5 will have props stuck in the middle unable to get a bonus, so it's almost worthless building anything but 5x? rooms, but sometimes you have to simply to get the damn narrator to shut up about how the crypt isn't big enough for all the corpses.  The game also seems intent on getting you to advance. Dungeon Keeper almost never rushed you. You could stay safe inside your walls until the lack of gold forced you out. WFTO, however? I think even the tutorial rushes you. Not even just for the achievement involved with finishing it quickly; it's do or die ASAP. And that rushed feeling follows you through the whole game. One of the final missions barely gives you enough time to get your workers digging out a single room before the enemy breaks into your space, and it's a constant, annoying, boring fight from that point on, from multiple directions, with no rest involved and nothing but luck to see you through. My last two attempts at that level followed the same tactics, the same speed, the same room layout planning at the very start. Three hours after the first one started, a single mistake put me in an unrecoverable death spiral that really shouldn't have been unrecoverable, and the attempt after that was a cheap and easy win for me in less than 15 minutes. Pure luck involved, nothing to do with choices or careful planning.  TL;DR: it'll satisfy your appetite for a modern Dungeon Keeper game, but like chinese take-out you'll be hungry again after an hour.
Love it!

Really Enjoyable. Level 6 was a snag but got through it eventually.  If you enjoyed playing Dungeon Keeper then you'll enjoy this.  Its very similar but it does have its own quirky levels.  I still play DK2 fairly frequently now but since buying this a few days ago it has been taking all of the little free time I have.  I've found myself yelling at the characters a few times when they seemed dumbstruck and just let themselves get hit without damaging back. The camera shape on the map doesn't seem to represent the area you are viewing on the screen either, it just feels off. This makes using the map to click to a different area very hit or miss. The levels do feel like they force you to complete them before you really want to. Quite often I'll hardly have established any base and I'll already be fighting the enemy and once you start they just continue to keep rolling in. I wouldn't mind but its starting to feel like this is EVERY level but aside from those bits it seems to play really well.
